b:["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"{\"@context\":\"https://schema.org\",\"@type\":\"WebSite\",\"name\":\"Expats Argentina\",\"url\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\",\"description\":\"Visa guides, cost of living, and expert advice for expats in all 24 provinces of Argentina.\",\"publisher\":{\"@type\":\"Organization\",\"name\":\"Expats Argentina\",\"url\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\"}}"}}]
c:["$","$L14",null,{}]
d:["$","$1","c",{"children":[null,["$","$L4",null,{"parallelRouterKey":"children","error":"$undefined","errorStyles":"$undefined","errorScripts":"$undefined","template":["$","$L5",null,{}],"templateStyles":"$undefined","templateScripts":"$undefined","notFound":"$undefined","forbidden":"$undefined","unauthorized":"$undefined"}]]}]
15:Tc2c,{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"FAQPage","mainEntity":[{"@type":"Question","name":"What are the biggest culture shocks for expats in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"The biggest shocks are the late schedule (dinner at 10pm, parties starting at midnight), the flexible relationship with time (people are chronically late by 30-60 minutes), the physical closeness during conversations, the kiss-on-the-cheek greeting for everyone, and the siesta hours when businesses close from 1-4pm. The indirect communication style also surprises many—'maybe' usually means 'no' and 'yes' often means 'maybe.'"}},{"@type":"Question","name":"How does tipping work in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Tip 10% at sit-down restaurants—leave it in cash even if paying by card, as waiters receive cash tips directly. Check your bill for 'cubierto' (cover charge) or 'servicio' (service charge), which is separate from the tip. At cafes, round up or leave small change. Delivery drivers get a small tip. Tipping is not expected at bars unless you're at a table with service."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"What time do Argentines eat dinner?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Argentines typically eat dinner between 9pm and 11pm. Restaurants don't get busy until 9:30pm, and trying to dine at 7pm will likely mean an empty restaurant or a closed kitchen. The daily eating schedule is: light breakfast (8-9am), main lunch (1-2pm), merienda afternoon snack with coffee and pastries (5-7pm), and then late dinner."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"What is mate etiquette in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Mate is a shared drink passed in a circle. The cebador (server) prepares and fills it, drinks the first bitter sip, then refills and passes to the next person. Drink the entire gourd, then pass it back to the cebador—not to the next person. Never move or stir the bombilla (metal straw). Say 'gracias' only when you want to stop drinking, as it signals you're done. Refusing mate when offered can be seen as rude."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"How do Argentines feel about personal space?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Argentines have a much smaller personal space bubble than North Americans or Northern Europeans. They stand close during conversations, touch your arm or shoulder while talking, and lean in. This is not flirting or aggression—it's cultural warmth. The cheek kiss greeting applies to everyone regardless of gender, and at gatherings you must greet and say goodbye to each person individually."}},{"@type":"Question","name":"What's the work-life balance like in Argentina?","acceptedAnswer":{"@type":"Answer","text":"Argentines prioritize relationships and leisure over work. Sunday is sacred family time with mandatory asados. Social gatherings go very late because people value connection. Businesses close for siesta. The concept of 'living to work' is foreign here—Argentines work to live. Expect a slower pace, longer lunches, and less urgency around deadlines compared to the US or Northern Europe."}}]}e:["$","$1","c",{"children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex flex-col min-h-screen","children":[["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"{\"@context\":\"https://schema.org\",\"@type\":\"BreadcrumbList\",\"itemListElement\":[{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":1,\"name\":\"Home\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com\"},{\"@type\":\"ListItem\",\"position\":2,\"name\":\"Culture\",\"item\":\"https://expatsargentina.com/culture\"}]}"}}],["$","script",null,{"type":"application/ld+json","dangerouslySetInnerHTML":{"__html":"$15"}}],"$L16","$L17","$L18","$L19","$L1a","$L1b","$L1c","$L1d","$L1e","$L1f","$L20","$L21","$L22"]}],["$L23"],"$L24"]}]
f:["$","$1","h",{"children":[null,["$","$L25",null,{"children":"$L26"}],["$","div",null,{"hidden":true,"children":["$","$L27",null,{"children":["$","$28",null,{"name":"Next.Metadata","children":"$L29"}]}]}],["$","meta",null,{"name":"next-size-adjust","content":""}]]}]

The cebador (server) fills it, drinks the first one (it's always bitter), then refills and passes. You drink the full gourd, then pass it back—don't say 'gracias' unless you want to stop drinking."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-rose-50 dark:bg-rose-950/20 p-4 rounded-lg border-l-4 border-rose-400 mb-4","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm italic","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"font-semibold not-italic","children":"Common expat experience:"}]," ","I said 'thank you' after my first sip because I'm polite. The group went quiet. Someone explained that 'gracias' means 'I'm done, don't give me more.' I had to awkwardly ask to rejoin the mate circle. The shame still haunts me."]}]}],["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-start gap-2 text-sm","children":[["$","$L32",null,{"size":"sm","className":"text-amber-500 flex-shrink-0 mt-0.5"}],["$","span",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","strong",null,{"children":"Pro tip:"}]," ","Don't move the bombilla (metal straw). Don't stir it. You don't touch the meat, you don't flip the meat, you don't even suggest when it might be done. Bring wine or a side dish, but never try to help with the grill unless asked."}],"$L33","$L34"]}]}],"$L35","$L36"]}]]}]}]}]

Many landlords prefer cash rent. Some restaurants offer discounts for cash. It means being aware, not showing off valuables, and not putting yourself in obviously risky situations."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-red-50 dark:bg-red-950/20 p-4 rounded-lg border-l-4 border-red-400","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm italic","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"font-semibold not-italic","children":"Common expat experience:"}]," ","A local friend explained this phrase after I left my laptop bag unattended at a cafe. Vegetarians exist but are often met with confusion and concern for their health."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-orange-50 dark:bg-orange-950/20 p-4 rounded-lg border-l-4 border-orange-400","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm italic","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"font-semibold not-italic","children":"Common expat experience:"}]," ","I'm vegetarian. When I tell Argentines this, they look at me with genuine worry. 'But... why? Are you sick?' At asados, hosts panic and grill me an entire zucchini. I've learned to just say 'I eat everything' and quietly avoid the meat."]}]}]]}]}],["$","div","1",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Vegetarian Struggles"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Vegetarianism is growing but still niche. Many 'vegetarian' dishes contain meat products. Empanadas will have meat in them unless specified. Took a bite. Definitely had ham in it. 'Oh, that's just for flavor,' the waiter said when I asked. Now I specify 'sin carne, sin jamón, sin pollo' (no meat, no ham, no chicken) every time."]}]}]]}]}],["$","div","2",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Coffee Culture"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"There is no drip coffee. Your options are espresso, cortado (espresso with a splash of milk), or café con leche (coffee with lots of milk). Starbucks exists but locals prefer traditional cafes."}],["$","div",null,{"className":"bg-orange-50 dark:bg-orange-950/20 p-4 rounded-lg border-l-4 border-orange-400","children":["$","p",null,{"className":"text-sm italic","children":[["$","span",null,{"className":"font-semibold not-italic","children":"Common expat experience:"}]," ","I asked for 'just a regular coffee' at a cafe. The waiter stared at me. '¿Cortado? ¿Con leche?' I didn't know the options. Now I'm a cortado person. It's better than drip anyway. I sit for hours with one cup and nobody rushes me."]}]}]]}]}],"$L3f","$L40"]}]]}]}]}]
1e:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl This"]}],["$","ul",null,{"className":"space-y-2 text-sm text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","li",null,{"children":"• Walk with your phone visible"}],["$","li",null,{"children":"• Wear flashy at an asado"}],["$","li",null,{"children":"• Ask for drip coffee (it doesn't exist)"}],["$","li",null,{"children":"• Take 'yes' at face value"}],["$","li",null,{"children":"• Rush through greetings at gatherings"}]]}]]}]]}]}]}]]}]}]}]
1f:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16 bg-gradient-to-b from-sky-50 to-white dark:from-sky-950/20 dark:to-background","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"container mx-auto px-4","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto text-center","children":[["$","$L2a",null,{"size":"xl","className":"mx-auto mb-6 text-rose-500"}],["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-6","children":"The Real Secret"}],["$","div",null,{"className":"prose prose-lg max-w-none text-muted-foreground","children":[["$","p",null,{"className":"mb-4","children":"You're going to make mistakes. You'll say 'gracias' at the wrong time, show up early to a party, try to pay with a large bill at a small shop. It's fine. Argentines are incredibly forgiving, especially if you show genuine interest in their culture."}],["$","p",null,{"className":"mb-4","children":"The mistakes are part of the experience. The awkward moments become the stories you laugh about later. And once you start getting it right—when you naturally lean in for the cheek kiss, when you pass the mate without thinking, when you sit down to dinner at 10 PM like it's normal—you'll feel like you actually belong here."}],["$","p",null,{"children":"That's the magic of Buenos Aires. It challenges you, confuses you, and eventually adopts you. Embrace the chaos. It's worth it."}]]}]]}]}]}]

21:["$","section",null,{"className":"py-16 md:py-24 bg-gray-50","children":["$","div",null,{"className":"max-w-3xl mx-auto px-4","children":[["$","h2",null,{"className":"text-3xl font-bold mb-8","children":"Frequently Asked Questions"}],["$","$L43",null,{"type":"single","collapsible":true,"className":"w-full","children":[["$","$L44","0",{"value":"faq-0","children":[["$","$L45",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"What are the biggest culture shocks for expats in Argentina?"}],["$","$L46",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"The biggest shocks are the late schedule (dinner at 10pm, parties starting at midnight), the flexible relationship with time (people are chronically late by 30-60 minutes), the physical closeness during conversations, the kiss-on-the-cheek greeting for everyone, and the siesta hours when businesses close from 1-4pm. The indirect communication style also surprises many—'maybe' usually means 'no' and 'yes' often means 'maybe.'"}]]}],["$","$L44","1",{"value":"faq-1","children":[["$","$L45",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"How does tipping work in Argentina?"}],["$","$L46",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Tip 10% at sit-down restaurants—leave it in cash even if paying by card, as waiters receive cash tips directly. Check your bill for 'cubierto' (cover charge) or 'servicio' (service charge), which is separate from the tip. At cafes, round up or leave small change. Delivery drivers get a small tip. Tipping is not expected at bars unless you're at a table with service."}]]}],["$","$L44","2",{"value":"faq-2","children":[["$","$L45",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"What time do Argentines eat dinner?"}],["$","$L46",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Argentines typically eat dinner between 9pm and 11pm. Restaurants don't get busy until 9:30pm, and trying to dine at 7pm will likely mean an empty restaurant or a closed kitchen. The daily eating schedule is: light breakfast (8-9am), main lunch (1-2pm), merienda afternoon snack with coffee and pastries (5-7pm), and then late dinner."}]]}],["$","$L44","3",{"value":"faq-3","children":[["$","$L45",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"What is mate etiquette in Argentina?"}],["$","$L46",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Mate is a shared drink passed in a circle. The cebador (server) prepares and fills it, drinks the first bitter sip, then refills and passes to the next person. Drink the entire gourd, then pass it back to the cebador—not to the next person. Never move or stir the bombilla (metal straw). Say 'gracias' only when you want to stop drinking, as it signals you're done. Refusing mate when offered can be seen as rude."}]]}],["$","$L44","4",{"value":"faq-4","children":[["$","$L45",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"How do Argentines feel about personal space?"}],["$","$L46",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Argentines have a much smaller personal space bubble than North Americans or Northern Europeans. They stand close during conversations, touch your arm or shoulder while talking, and lean in. This is not flirting or aggression—it's cultural warmth. The cheek kiss greeting applies to everyone regardless of gender, and at gatherings you must greet and say goodbye to each person individually."}]]}],["$","$L44","5",{"value":"faq-5","children":[["$","$L45",null,{"className":"text-left","children":"What's the work-life balance like in Argentina?"}],["$","$L46",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground","children":"Argentines prioritize relationships and leisure over work. Sunday is sacred family time with mandatory asados. Social gatherings go very late because people value connection. Businesses close for siesta. The concept of 'living to work' is foreign here—Argentines work to live. Expect a slower pace, longer lunches, and less urgency around deadlines compared to the US or Northern Europe."}]]}]]}]]}]}]

The host gently but firmly moved me away from the grill. Later, a friend explained that questioning the asador is like telling someone's grandmother her pasta sauce needs more salt. Just don't."]}]}]

36:["$","div","4",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Greeting Everyone Individually"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"When arriving at a gathering, you greet and kiss everyone individually. 37:["$","div","3",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Sarcasm and Humor"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Argentine humor is dry, self-deprecating, and often dark. 39:["$","div","3",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"The 'Vuelto' Issue"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Small bills and coins are precious. San Telmo and La Boca require more caution, especially after dark. 3d:["$","div","4",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","div",null,{"className":"flex items-start gap-3 mb-2","children":[false,["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg","children":"Common Scams"}]]}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Mustard/pigeon poop scams (distracting you while someone robs you), fake taxi overcharges, and the 'dropped money' trick are common. 3f:["$","div","3",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Bakeries (Panaderías)"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Facturas (pastries) and medialunas (croissants, but sweeter) are breakfast staples. 40:["$","div","4",{"data-slot":"card","className":"bg-card text-card-foreground flex flex-col gap-6 rounded-xl border py-6 shadow-sm","children":["$","div",null,{"data-slot":"card-content","className":"px-6 pt-6","children":[["$","h3",null,{"className":"font-semibold text-lg mb-2","children":"Delivery Apps"}],["$","p",null,{"className":"text-muted-foreground mb-4","children":"Rappi and PedidosYa dominate food delivery. 26:[["$","meta","0",{"charSet":"utf-8"}],["$","meta","1",{"name":"viewport","content":"width=device-width, initial-scale=1"}]]
4a:I[17124,["/_next/static/chunks/f7a6a5c10098787e.js","/_next/static/chunks/0228e4c449c3a8b8.js"],"IconMark"]
29:[["$","title","0",{"children":"Argentine Culture & Social Norms - A Guide for Expats | Expats Argentina"}],["$","meta","1",{"name":"description","content":"The unwritten rules of Argentine culture. Learn about mate etiquette, social customs, the kiss greeting, time schedules, and how to avoid looking like a tourist."}],["$","meta","2",{"name":"author","content":"Expats Argentina"}],["$","meta","3",{"name":"keywords","content":"Argentine culture,Argentina social norms,mate etiquette,Buenos Aires customs,expat guide Argentina"}],["$","meta","4",{"name":"creator","content":"Expats Argentina"}],["$","meta","5",{"name":"robots","content":"index, follow"}],["$","meta","6",{"name":"googlebot","content":"index, follow, max-video-preview:-1, max-image-preview:large,
